data.text: Agreed, but I recently broke my ankle and needed surgery. Local bike shop are suggesting I use flat pedals because clipping out may hurt during recovery. Just today I bought a pair of stiff sole Pro-Riders to use with temporary flat pedals. Back to SPD asap!
data.author: Todd McKinnon

data.text: Weird ! I once had a roommate named Todd and his brother's name was McKinnon ! Anyway, I'm sorry your injury. That's a tough one. I'd start with the pedals retention wide open and then possibly try the easy release cleate that are available. But that's a risk for you to take üòÅ speedy recovery !!!

data.text: Only when I'm test riding bikes at the shop and wearing trainers. Running shoes have the worst tread pattern for flat pedals, plus that squishy inefficiency. Skate shoes with proper orthotics are what I wear most of the time on flat pedals..

data.text: Ha no, way to much flex, to squishy, drop is to high, fit is wrong for pedals, the soles won't last at all. Cycling shoes or Nike SB for the city bike

data.text: I agree. A BIG Negative to running shoes! Coming from someone who swears-by clipless. Gotta have that rigid sole so you're not losing energy under the shoe.

data.text: Running shoes made for running, cycling shoes for cycling. Everything in between is just riding around town ,shopping, spinning a bit for wellness üôÇ There is still some flat pedal shoes which are made for touringbikes ,Bmx ,trial, all mountain, Downhill , etc.... You can get better shoes then running shoes ,and they are still very comfortable .
